content: F.B.I. <span class="fa fa-info-circle">headquarterspan>s in Washington. Sixteen states let the F.B.I. use the technology to compare the faces of suspected criminals to driver’s license and ID photos. ![Newspaper Shooting Shows Widening Use of Facial Recognition by Authorities](https://static01.nyt.com/images/2018/06/30/business/30FACE-1/merlin_139530060_1e4c5c2f-ecca-44e9-8760-3949334b2cba-superJumbo.jpg?quality=90&auto=webp) <span class="fa fa-info-circle">SANspan> FRANCISCO — When the police <span class="fa fa-info-circle">apprehendspan>ed a suspect for the shootings at The Capital <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Gazettespan>’s <span class="fa fa-info-circle">newsroomspan> in <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Annapolisspan>, Md., on Thursday, he refused to <span class="fa fa-info-circle">divulgespan> his name. So the authorities identified the man, <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Jarrodspan> <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Ramspan>os, using a different method: facial <span class="fa fa-info-circle">recognitionspan> technology. The <span class="fa fa-info-circle">revelationspan> <span class="fa fa-info-circle">shonespan> a spotlight on just how easily and how quickly officials can <span class="fa fa-info-circle">pinpointspan> suspects using a technology that is increasingly <span class="fa fa-info-circle">pervasivespan> in law <span class="fa fa-info-circle">enforcementspan>. Over the past few years, facial <span class="fa fa-info-circle">recognitionspan> has been quietly adopted by the authorities across the United States — including at the local policing level — and become part of the standard law <span class="fa fa-info-circle">enforcementspan> toolkit. Sixteen states let the Federal <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Bureauspan> of Investigation use the technology to compare the faces of suspected criminals to driver’s license and ID photos, according to a report from the Georgetown Law Center on Privacy and Technology. And thanks to recent improvements to facial <span class="fa fa-info-circle">recognitionspan> by some of the world’s largest tech companies, its influence in policing is likely to grow. “Face <span class="fa fa-info-circle">recognitionspan> is one of the most important developments in crime fighting since the <span class="fa fa-info-circle">discoveryspan> of fingerprinting in the 19th century,” said Joseph J. Atick, a pioneer in face <span class="fa fa-info-circle">recognitionspan> technology and <span class="fa fa-info-circle">executivespan> chairman of ID4Africa, which works with African governments to institute national identification systems. “It’s hard to imagine a police <span class="fa fa-info-circle">departmentspan> in the United States with more than 10 to 15 <span class="fa fa-info-circle">copspan>s in it that does not have access to face <span class="fa fa-info-circle">recognitionspan>.” The use of the technology in the Capital <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Gazettespan> shooting comes amid a broader debate about facial <span class="fa fa-info-circle">recognitionspan>’s role in policing. <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Proponentspan>s see it as a powerful tool for catching criminals, but civil liberties experts have warned that it can be an <span class="fa fa-info-circle">instrumentspan> of mass surveillance that threatens people’s ability to <span class="fa fa-info-circle">anonymouslyspan> go about their business. That debate has heated up as tech companies like Amazon have recently drawn <span class="fa fa-info-circle">criticismspan> for providing facial <span class="fa fa-info-circle">recognitionspan> technology to law <span class="fa fa-info-circle">enforcementspan> agencies. Last month, more than two dozen civil rights <span class="fa fa-info-circle">organizationspan>s asked Amazon to stop selling its facial <span class="fa fa-info-circle">recognitionspan> system — called Rekognition — to the authorities. The civil rights groups argued that Rekognition was overly powerful — according to Amazon’s web site, it can not only track individuals, it can also <span class="fa fa-info-circle">detectspan> “up to 100 faces in challenging crowded photos,” as well as license plates captured by traffic cameras. That means the system could potentially <span class="fa fa-info-circle">ensnarespan> many ordinary citizens, rather than being limited only to people committing crimes. In the case of the Capital <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Gazettespan> shooting, police did not use facial <span class="fa fa-info-circle">recognitionspan> in a way that violated people’s privacy, according to experts in the technology. They noted that the police were merely confirming the identity of a suspect whom they already had in <span class="fa fa-info-circle">custodyspan>, as <span class="fa fa-info-circle">opposespan>d to trying to find a criminal in an enormous database of people. <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Timothyspan> Altomare, chief of the Anne Arundel <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Countyspan> Police Department in <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Marylandspan>, said on Friday that the police used the <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Marylandspan> Image <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Repositoryspan> System to identify Mr. <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Ramspan>os when he did not <span class="fa fa-info-circle">cooperatespan> with <span class="fa fa-info-circle">investigatorspan>s. They <span class="fa fa-info-circle">initiallyspan> tried to learn Mr. <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Ramspan>os’s identity through his fingerprints, he said. But with the fingerprint identification moving slowly, they quickly switched to facial <span class="fa fa-info-circle">recognitionspan>. <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Specificallyspan>, a photo of Mr. <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Ramspan>os was sent to the <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Marylandspan> <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Coordinationspan> and Analysis Center, which searched the <span class="fa fa-info-circle">repositoryspan> of driver’s license photos and <span class="fa fa-info-circle">mugspan> shots to find a match, said Mr. Altomare. “We would have been much longer in identifying him and being able to push forward,” Mr. Altomare said about why the image system was used. The <span class="fa fa-info-circle">progressionspan> of facial <span class="fa fa-info-circle">recognitionspan> technology has been rapid. Computing systems can now examine a photo or video <span class="fa fa-info-circle">footagespan> of a face and match it to an image in an existing database of faces, all with an <span class="fa fa-info-circle">accuracyspan> that rivals human sight, something that was not possible just five years ago. These systems also typically scan databases far quicker than human analysts. Even in the technology’s earliest days, it <span class="fa fa-info-circle">piquespan>d the interest of intelligence agencies and law <span class="fa fa-info-circle">enforcementspan> officials. American military and intelligence agencies used facial <span class="fa fa-info-circle">recognitionspan> for years in Iraq and Afghanistan to identify potential terrorists. More recently, it has caught on at dozens of police <span class="fa fa-info-circle">departmentspan>s around the United States to pursue drug dealers, <span class="fa fa-info-circle">prostitutespan>s and other conventional criminal suspects. That adoption is likely to <span class="fa fa-info-circle">acceleratespan> as more companies — such as Amazon, NEC and Cognitec — widen their facial <span class="fa fa-info-circle">recognitionspan> offerings. The <span class="fa fa-info-circle">hardwarespan> and software that underpins the technology has also become less expensive, pushing <span class="fa fa-info-circle">myriadspan> start-ups and other companies to enter the market. Police <span class="fa fa-info-circle">departmentspan>s and individuals can even build similar technology on their own with relative ease. “If a police <span class="fa fa-info-circle">departmentspan> hired me for a summer <span class="fa fa-info-circle">internshipspan>, I could cook them up a decent face <span class="fa fa-info-circle">recognitionspan> <span class="fa fa-info-circle">algorithmspan> — not that I am offering my services,” said Jonathan Frankle, an <span class="fa fa-info-circle">artificialspan> intelligence researcher at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology who helped write a study of face <span class="fa fa-info-circle">recognitionspan> technology at the Georgetown Law Center for Privacy and Technology. Questions about privacy and concerns about potential <span class="fa fa-info-circle">misusespan> of facial <span class="fa fa-info-circle">recognitionspan> are also likely to increase, especially as the systems require a large database of images that faces can be matched against. The F.B.I. has a database that spans 400 million images, according to a recent report from the General Accounting Office. The <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Marylandspan> Image <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Repositoryspan> System contains millions of images from <span class="fa fa-info-circle">motorspan> vehicle records. Many local law <span class="fa fa-info-circle">enforcementspan> agencies may run criminal searches against state databases of driver’s license photos, involving millions of citizens in a kind of government surveillance they didn’t sign up for, said Jennifer <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Lynchspan>, a <span class="fa fa-info-circle">seniorspan> staff lawyer at the Electronic <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Frontierspan> <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Foundationspan>, a digital rights <span class="fa fa-info-circle">organizationspan>. “People who are in a driver’s license database did not agree to be part of a criminal search every time the police are looking for a suspect,” Ms. <span class="fa fa-info-circle">Lynchspan> said. “A civil photograph should not be subject to search for criminal purposes.” One added concern is that face <span class="fa fa-info-circle">recognitionspan> systems sometimes make mistakes, matching an image to the wrong person. “Depending on how good your image is, the <span class="fa fa-info-circle">accuracyspan> can vary wildly,” Mr. Frankle said. That’s especially so when photos are taken by <span class="fa fa-info-circle">overheadspan> security cameras, which do not always provide a clear and straightforward image. Even in good conditions, face <span class="fa fa-info-circle">recognitionspan> technology fails at least part of the time. And those failures may increase as databases of potential suspects grow and there are more chances of mistaken outcomes, said Mr. Frankle. “The <span class="fa fa-info-circle">accuracyspan> of these systems depends on so many things, including the size of your database,” said Mr. Frankle. “The technology may get worse as the database gets bigger.”

title: Newspaper Shooting Shows Widening Use of Facial Recognition by Authorities

paperStatistics.title: Newspaper Shooting Shows Widening Use of Facial Recognition by Authorities
paperStatistics.desc: F.B.I. headquarters in Washington. Sixteen states let the F.B.I. use the technology to compare the faces of suspected criminals to driver’s license and ID photos.
